title: RS21824
content: During the debates over the 1998 HEA amendments, campus crimes, particularly drug-related incidents, were a major concern for Congress. Despite a general decrease in campus crime rates, the number of drug-related incidents on campuses was on the rise. Representative Souder highlighted the growing epidemic of drug abuse and proposed student eligibility provisions as a crucial first step in addressing this issue. During the 1998 HEA reauthorization discussions, Representative Souder emphasized the increasing drug abuse epidemic on college campuses. As a response, Congress added a provision to P.L. 105-244, stating that students convicted of drug-related crimes would be ineligible for federal student assistance under Title IV of the HEA. The legislation under P.L. 105-244 makes students convicted of drug-related crimes ineligible for federal student assistance under Title IV of the HEA based on the type and number of convictions. Students with multiple convictions for possession or selling controlled substances become indefinitely ineligible. A student becomes indefinitely ineligible for federal student assistance under Title IV of the HEA if they have more than two convictions for possession or more than one conviction for selling a controlled substance. The period of ineligibility begins on the date of the charge and ends after a specified interval for each offense. The ineligibility period for federal student assistance due to drug convictions is as follows: Possession - First offense: one year, Second offense: two years, Third offense: indefinite. Sale - First offense: two years, Second offense: indefinite. Convictions prior to turning 18 may not count. According to the 2006-2007 Federal Student Aid Handbook, drug convictions prior to turning 18 or overturned convictions do not affect eligibility for federal financial assistance. Indefinitely ineligible students must complete a drug rehabilitation program to regain eligibility. Eligible programs must meet specific requirements outlined in program regulations. Indefinitely ineligible individuals for federal financial assistance must complete a drug rehabilitation program to regain eligibility. The program must meet specific requirements outlined in regulations, including receiving funds from government programs or licensed entities. To regain eligibility for federal financial assistance, indefinitely ineligible individuals must complete a drug rehabilitation program that meets specific requirements, including receiving funds from government programs or licensed entities. The program must also be administered or recognized by a licensed hospital, health clinic, or medical doctor, and include at least two unannounced drug tests. Participation in the program reduces the ineligibility period based on the number of convictions for possession of a controlled substance. Upon completion of a drug rehabilitation program, individuals with multiple convictions for possession of a controlled substance can reduce their ineligibility period for federal financial aid. Future convictions will reinstate the ineligibility. Over 180,000 students have been affected by this policy. Upon completion of a drug rehabilitation program, students can reduce their ineligibility for federal financial aid. Future convictions will make them ineligible again. More than 180,000 students have been affected by this policy, with California and Texas having a high number of ineligible students. The Deficit Reduction Act of 2005 changed the implementation of a provision affecting federal financial aid eligibility for students with drug convictions. California and Texas had a high number of ineligible students due to this provision. The amended provision specifies that only drug convictions while enrolled in postsecondary education and receiving Title IV aid would disqualify a student from federal student aid. The period of ineligibility remains based on the type and recency of the conviction, and the number of prior convictions. Title IV of the HEA may be considered in the upcoming reauthorization. The period of ineligibility for federal student aid due to drug convictions depends on the type, recency, and number of prior convictions. Legislative proposals are being considered to modify this provision in Title IV of the HEA. Issues surrounding implementation, penalties, and who should be penalized continue to be debated. During discussions on reauthorization, the addition of a provision to student eligibility requirements in 1998 was influenced by concerns about drug usage on college campuses and the rise in drug-related crimes reported by institutions nationwide. Policymakers debated how to implement the provision, what penalties to impose, who should be penalized, and whether other crimes should disqualify students from receiving financial aid. During the 1998 reauthorization, policymakers expressed concern about the increasing drug-related crimes on college campuses, leading to the inclusion of a provision for eligibility. Critics argue that singling out drug convictions for financial aid consequences is unfair compared to other crimes like rape, arson, or armed robbery. Supporters maintain that drug-related crimes are more prevalent on campuses. Representative Frank argues that focusing on drug convictions for financial aid consequences is unfair compared to other crimes like rape, arson, or armed robbery. Supporters justify this focus by stating that drug-related crimes are more common on college campuses. The implications of limiting financial aid eligibility to drug-related crimes may be considered during reauthorization, with potential concerns about addressing other illegal behaviors like alcohol abuse on campuses. During reauthorization, limiting financial aid eligibility for drug-related crimes may be reconsidered. The existing provision does not differentiate between misdemeanor or felony convictions, resulting in loss of eligibility regardless of jail time served. Separate ineligibility periods for selling versus possession of controlled substances acknowledge a distinction between offenses. The existing provision for limiting financial aid eligibility for drug-related crimes does not differentiate between misdemeanor or felony convictions, leading to loss of eligibility regardless of jail time served. Distinctions are made between selling and possession of controlled substances, acknowledging a difference between offenses. Congress may also debate the impact of felony versus misdemeanor drug convictions on student aid eligibility.
